Navigation
Name Rascal/Statements/Assignment
Synopsis Assign a value to a variable.
Syntax Assignable AssignmentOp Exp

where AssignmentOp may be one of =, +=, -=, *=, /=, or ?=.

An Assignable is one of the following:
  1. Var
  2. Assignable [ Exp ]
  3. Assignable . Name
  4. < Assignable1, Assignable2, ..., Assignablen >
  5. Assignable ? Exp
  6. Assignable @ Name
  7. Name ( Assignable1, Assignable2, ... )
Description The purpose of an assignment is to assign a new value to a simple variable or to an element of a more complex data structure.

The standard assignment operator is =. The other assignment operators can be expressed as abbreviations for the standard assignment operator.
Assignment Operator Equivalent to
Assignable += Exp Assignable = Assignable + Exp
Assignable -= Exp Assignable = Assignable - Exp
Assignable *= Exp Assignable = Assignable * Exp
Assignable /= Exp Assignable = Assignable / Exp
Assignable &= Exp Assignable = Assignable & Exp
Assignable ?= Exp Assignable = Assignable ? Exp


An assignable is either a single variable, (the base variable), optionally followed by subscriptions or field selections. The assignment statement always results in assigning a completely new value to the base variable. We distinguish the following forms of assignment:
  1. Variable assignable Var = Exp: The expression Exp is evaluated and its value is assigned to the base variable Var.
  2. Subscription assignable Assignable [ Exp1] = Exp2: First the value V of Assignable is determined. Next the value of Exp1 is used as index in V and the value of Exp2 replaces the original value at that index position. The result is a new value V' that is assigned to the Assignable.
  3. Field assignable Assignable . Name = Exp: The value V of Assignable is determined and should be of a type that has a field Name. The value of that field is replaced in V by the value of Exp resulting in a new value V' that is assigned to Assignable.
  4. Multiple assignable < Assignable1, Assignable2, ..., Assignablen > = Exp: First the value Exp is determined and should be a tuple of the form <V1, V2, ..., Vn>. Next the assignments Assignablei = Vi are performed for 1 <= i <= n.
  5. IsDefined Assignable Assignable ? Exp2 = Exp: First the value of Exp is determined and if that is defined it is assigned to Assignable. Otherwise, the value of Exp2 is assigned to Assignable.
  6. Annotation assignable Assignable @ Name = Exp: The value V of Assignable is determined and should be of a type that has an annotation Name. The value of that annotation is replaced in V by the value of Exp resulting in a new value V' that is assigned to Assignable. See Annotation.
  7. Constructor assignable Name ( Assignable1, Assignable2, ..., Assignablen) = Exp: First the value Exp is determined and should be a data value of the form `Name(V1, V2, ..., Vn). Next the assignments Assignablei = Vi are performed for 1 <= i <= n.
Examples 1. Variable assignable: 
rascal>N = 3;
int: 3
rascal>N;
Undeclared variable, function or constructor: N
2. Subscription assignable with a list: 
rascal>L = [10,20,30];
list[int]: [10,20,30]
rascal>P = L;
Undeclared variable, function or constructor: Lrascal>L[1] = 200;
Uninitialized variable: |eval:///?command=L%5B1%5D+%3D+200%3B|(0,1,<1,0>,<1,1>):class org.rascalmpl.semantics.dynamic.Assignable$Variable
Observe that P is unchanged: 
rascal>P;
Undeclared variable, function or constructor: P
2. Subscription assignable with a map: 
rascal>M = ("abc": 1, "def" : 2);
map[str, int]: ("def":2,"abc":1)
rascal>M["def"] = 3;
Uninitialized variable: |eval:///?command=M%5B%22def%22%5D+%3D+3%3B|(0,1,<1,0>,<1,1>):class org.rascalmpl.semantics.dynamic.Assignable$Variable
2. Subscription assignable to a tuple: 
rascal>T = <1, "abc", true>;
tuple[int,str,bool]: <1,"abc",true>
rascal>T[1] = "def";
Uninitialized variable: |eval:///?command=T%5B1%5D+%3D+%22def%22%3B|(0,1,<1,0>,<1,1>):class org.rascalmpl.semantics.dynamic.Assignable$Variable
3. Field assignable: 
rascal>data FREQ = wf(str word, int freq);
ok
rascal>W = wf("rascal", 1000);
Undeclared variable, function or constructor: wfrascal>W.freq = 100000;
Uninitialized variable: |eval:///?command=W.freq+%3D+100000%3B|(0,1,<1,0>,<1,1>):class org.rascalmpl.semantics.dynamic.Assignable$Variable
4. Multiple assignable: 
rascal> = <"abc", 2.5, [1,2,3]>;
tuple[str,real,list[int]]: <"abc",2.5,[1,2,3]>
rascal>A;
Undeclared variable, function or constructor: Arascal>B;
Undeclared variable, function or constructor: Brascal>C;
Undeclared variable, function or constructor: C
5. isDefined assignable. First we explore the ?= assignment operator (recall that N already got a value above; X was never assigned a value): 
rascal>N ?= 5;
int: 5
rascal>X;
Undeclared variable, function or constructor: Xrascal>X ?= 3;
int: 3
Next consider, the isDefined assignable itself; recall that earlier we assigned a map value to M and that it does not contain the key "cef" so essentially we try to increment a non-existing map entry: 
rascal>M["cef"] ? 0 += 1;
internal exception: java.lang.NullPointerException	somewhere in: markupScreen

6. Annotation assignable: 
rascal>anno str FREQ@color;
Undeclared type: FREQrascal>W @ color = "red";
Uninitialized variable: |eval:///?command=W+%40+color+%3D+%22red%22%3B|(0,1,<1,0>,<1,1>):class org.rascalmpl.semantics.dynamic.Assignable$Variable
